text: These are the words of the Preacher, the son of David and king in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Vanity of vanities,”
    says the Preacher;
“vanity of vanities,
    all is vanity.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
What benefit is there to a man in all his labors
    that he toils under the sun?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A generation comes, and a generation goes,
    but the earth continually remains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sun comes up, and the sun goes down,
    and hurries to the place where it rises.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It moves to the south,
    and then moves around to the north;
the wind continually travels around,
    and it keeps turning on its circuit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the streams flow into the sea,
    and the sea is never filled up.
And to the place where the streams flow,
    there they continually return to flow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All matters are wearisome;
    a man is not able to speak to them.
The eye is not satisfied with what it sees,
    and the ear is not content with what it hears.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Is there a matter where it is said,
    “See, this is truly new”?
Long ago in the past
    every matter has already been in our midst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is not a memory for the former things,
    and moreover, there will not be
a memory for the things coming after,
    even those things that are yet to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Preacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: I set my heart to seek and to investigate with wisdom everything that is done under heaven. It is a burdensome task that God has given to the sons of men, by which they may be occupied.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen everything that is done under the sun, and indeed, all is vanity and like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is bent cannot be straightened,
    and what is missing cannot be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: I spoke in my heart, saying, “I have been great and increased in wisdom more than anyone else who has been before me in Jerusalem, and my heart has had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And I set my heart to know wisdom and to know the folly of ideas and to know foolish behavior, and I know that this as well is like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For in an abundance of wisdom is an abundance of frustration,
    and he who increases in knowledge also increases in sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said in my heart, “Come, and I will test you with selfish pleasures to experience desires.” And notice that this too is vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said of frivolous fun, “They are only senseless ideas”; and regarding selfish pleasure, “What purpose is this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: I investigated how to cheer up my body with wine, while my heart was still guiding me with wisdom, in order to grasp folly until I might experience what is good for sons of men to do under heaven during the number of days that they might have life.
speaker: Narrator

text: I accomplished great works. I built houses for myself, and planted myself vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made for myself royal gardens and parks, and I planted in them all sorts of fruit trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made for myself pools of water to irrigate the forests of growing trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: I even bought male and female slaves; even some were born to me in my house. I had also great possessions of herds and flocks more than any who had been in Jerusalem before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also gathered for myself silver and gold and treasures of kings and provinces. I obtained singers, both men and women, and the delights of the sons of men, and many concubines.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I became great and surpassed anyone who had been in Jerusalem before me. All the while my wisdom remained with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And everything that my eyes wanted I did not refuse them.
    And I did not withhold my heart from any selfish pleasure,
for my heart was glad from all my efforts;
    and this was my reward for all my efforts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I turned to all the work that my hands had designed
    and all the labor that I had toiled to make;
and notice, all of it was vanity and chasing the wind.
    And there was no benefit under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I turned to consider wisdom,
    the folly of ideas, and foolish behavior;
for what else can a man do who comes after the king?
    Or what more than those have already done?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I saw that there is more benefit in wisdom than in foolishness,
    more benefit in light than in darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise man has eyes in his head so he sees where he walks,
    but the fool continues in darkness.
Yet I perceived
    that the same fate overtakes them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said in my heart,
“What happens to the fool will happen to me also.
    So to what advantage is my wisdom?”
Then I said to myself,
    “This also is vanity.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For there is no lasting memory for the wise or the fool,
    by which in the coming days everyone will be forgotten.
How the wise dies just like the fool!
speaker: Narrator

text: And I began to hate life for the labor that was done under the sun was contemptible to me, for all of this was vanity and chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I despised all the toil in which I labored under the sun, which I will give up to the man who comes after me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And who knows if this man will be wise or a fool? Yet he will gain power over every labor that I have toiled and my use of wisdom under the sun. Also this is vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I turned to give my heart up to despair concerning all the toil of my labors under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is a man who labors with wisdom, knowledge, and skill; yet to a man who did not labor for this, he leaves it as his inheritance. This also is vanity and a great distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what becomes of a man with all his labor and with the striving in his heart that he toils under the sun?
speaker: Narrator

text: For all his days are sorrowful, and his work is a vexation; even at night his heart finds no rest. Also this is fleeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is nothing better for a man than to eat and drink, and find enjoyment in his labor. This also, I saw, is from the hand of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who can even eat or have enjoyment more so than I?
speaker: Narrator

text: For to a man who is pleasing before Him, God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy; but to the sinner He gives the work of gathering and collecting to give him who is pleasing before God. Also this is vanity and chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To everything there is a season,
    a time for every purpose under heaven:
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to be born, and a time to die;
    a time to plant, and a time to uproot what is planted;
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to kill, and a time to heal;
    a time to break down, and a time to build up;
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to weep, and a time to laugh;
    a time to mourn, and a time to dance;
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones;
    a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to gain, and a time to lose;
    a time to keep, and a time to cast away;
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to tear, and a time to sew;
    a time to keep silence, and a time to speak;
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to love, and a time to hate;
    a time of war, and a time of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What benefit does the worker have in his toil?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen the task that God has given to sons of men to be concerned with.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has made everything beautiful in its appropriate time. He has also put obscurity in their hearts so that no one comes to know the work that God has done from the beginning to the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: I experienced that there is nothing better for them than to be glad and do good in their life.
speaker: Narrator

text: And also that everyone should eat and drink and experience good in all their labor. This is a gift of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have perceived that everything that God has done will be lasting. And to this there is nothing to be added, and from it there is nothing to be taken away. And God has done this so that in His presence men fear Him.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
I thought in my heart:
God will bring judgment
    to the righteous and the wicked,
for there is an appropriate time
    for every matter and deed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I thought in my heart: Regarding the account of sons of men, God is making clear to them to show that they are but animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what befalls the sons of men befalls animals; as one dies, so dies the other. There is one breath for all of them; there is no advantage for man any more than animals, for all is vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: All go to one place: All are from the dust and all return to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who knows whether the spirit of man goes upward and the spirit of animals goes down to the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text: So I saw that there is nothing better than that a man should rejoice in his labor, for that is his reward. For who will bring him to see what will happen after his life?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Again I saw all types of oppression that are done under the sun:
Look! The tears of the oppressed,
    and no one was there to comfort them.
And there was force from the hand of the oppressors,
    and no one was there to comfort them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I thought that fortunate were the dead
    who had already died,
even more than the living
    who were still alive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And still better than both
    is he who has not been,
who has not seen the evil deeds
    that are done under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw that all toil and every skillful work come from one man’s envy of another. This also is vanity and like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fool folds his hands
    and eats his own flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is a full hand of quietness
    than handfuls of toil and chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again, I saw vanity under the sun:
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a man who is alone,
    neither having son or brother,
and there is not an end to all his toil,
    and his eyes are not satisfied with riches to say,
“For whom do I labor
    and cause my life to lack good things?”
Also this is vanity
    and a burdensome task.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Two are better than one,
    because there is a good reward for their labor together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For if they fall,
    then one will help up his companion.
But woe to him who is alone when he falls
    and has no one to help him up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also if two lie down together, then they will keep warm;
    but how can one keep warm by himself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And if someone might overpower another by himself,
    two together can withstand him.
A threefold cord is not quickly broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Better is a poor and wise youth than an old and foolish king who will no longer be admonished.
speaker: Narrator

text: For out of prison he has come to reign, even though he was born poor in the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw all those who live and walk under the sun, along with the next youth who will arise in the king’s place.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no end of all the people, to all who were before them. Yet those who come later will not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Guard your steps when you enter the house of God, and draw near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they are doing evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be quick to speak with your mouth,
    nor let your heart be hasty to utter a word
    before God.
For God is in heaven,
    and you are on the earth;
    therefore may your words be few.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For a dream comes when there is a great burden,
    and a foolish voice when there are many words.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you make a vow to God, do not delay in fulfilling it because He has no pleasure in fools. Fulfill what you have vowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Better it is that you do not make a vow than you make a vow and not fulfill it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let your mouth cause you to sin, and do not say before the messenger that it was an error. Why should God be angry with your words and destroy the work of your hands?
speaker: Narrator

text: For when there is an abundance of dreams and futilities, then words increase too. Therefore it is God you should fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see in a district the oppression of the poor and the violent perversion of justice and righteousness, do not be astounded at the matter; for the high official is watched over by an even higher official, and there are even higher officials over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this is an advantage to the land in every way, like a king committed to a cultivated field.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When there is an increase of good things,
    then there is an increase of those who devour them.
And what profit have the owners
    except to see them with their eyes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sweet is the sleep of a laboring man,
    whether he eats a little or much;
but the abundance of the rich
    will not let him sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a grave misery that I have seen under the sun:
when riches were kept by an owner to his hurt,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As he came from his mother’s womb,
    naked shall he return, to go as he came;
he shall take nothing from his labor
    which he may carry away in his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This also is a grievous evil:
Just as he came,
    so shall he go.
    And what profit is there to him who toils for the wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moreover, in all his days he eats in darkness,
    while he is greatly irritated in sickness and anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what I have seen to be good: It is fitting to eat and drink and find enjoyment in all his labor in which he toils under the sun all the days of his life, which God has given to him; for this is his reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: And also everyone to whom God has given wealth and possessions, and given him power to enjoy them, and to receive his reward and to rejoice in his labor—this is the gift of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he will not much remember the days of his life because God keeps him occupied with joy in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is an evil that I have seen under the sun, and it lies heavy on mankind:
speaker: Narrator

text: a man to whom God gives wealth, possessions, and honor so that there is no want in his life from among anything that he desires; yet God does not give him ability to eat from them because another man eats and enjoys from his possessions. This is vanity and a tormenting injustice.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man fathers a hundred children and lives many years, so that the days of his years are many, but his soul is not satisfied with life’s good things, and he has no burial, I say that a stillborn child is better off than he—
speaker: Narrator

text: for it comes in vanity and departs in darkness, and in darkness its name is covered up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, it has not seen the sun or known anything, yet it finds rest rather than he.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though the man may live a thousand years, twice over, yet he does not see the good things. Does not everyone go to the same place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the labor of man is for his mouth,
    yet his appetite is not satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what benefit is there for the wise
    over the fool?
And what more does the poor man know
    who walks before others?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be content with the sight of eyes
    than to have a wandering appetite.
This is vanity
    and like chasing the wind.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The more words,
    the more vanity,
    so what profit is there to mankind?
speaker: Narrator

text: For who knows what is good for man while he lives the few days of his vain life which pass like a shadow? For who can tell men what will be after them under the sun?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A good name is better than precious ointment,
    and the day of death than the day of birth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is better to go to a house of mourning
    than to go to a house of feasting,
for this is the end of all mankind;
    and the living will lay it to heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grief is better than laughter,
    for with a downcast face the heart considers the good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heart of those who are wise is in the house of mourning,
    but the heart of those who are foolish in the house of feasting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is better to hear the rebuke from a wise man
    than a man listen to the song of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For like the crackling sound of thorns under a pot,
    so is the mocking laughter of fools.
    And this is also vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For oppression brings confusion to the wise man,
    and a bribe destroys a man’s heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The end of a matter is better than the beginning of it,
    and the patient in spirit than the haughty in spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be quick in your spirit to be angry,
    for irritation settles in the bosom of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not say, “Why were the earlier days better than these days?”
    For it is not from wisdom that you inquire this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is good with an inheritance,
    and an advantage to those who see the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the protection of wisdom
    is like the protection of money,
and the advantage of knowledge is
    that wisdom preserves the life of him who has it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Consider the work of God:
Who is able to make straight
    what He has made crooked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the day of prosperity be joyful,
    but in the day of distress consider:
God has made the one
    as well as the other.
For this reason man will not be able to understand
    anything that comes after him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen everything in my days of vanity:
There is the righteous man who dies in his righteousness,
    and there is the wicked man who extends his life of evil.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Wisdom strengthens the wise man
    more than ten rulers who are in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For there is not a righteous man on earth
    who only does good and refrains from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not give heed to everything people say,
    lest you hear your servant cursing you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your heart knows
    that many times you have spoken a curse against others.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All this I have tested by wisdom. I said,
“I will be wise,”
    but it was far from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That which is, is far off,
    and exceedingly deep.
    Who can find it out?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I turned my heart to know,
    and seek and search out wisdom in how things are
and to experience wicked folly,
    even foolishness and madness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I find more bitter than death
    the woman whose heart is snares
and nets,
    and whose hands are fetters.
He who pleases God escapes her,
    but the sinner is taken by her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“See, this is what I found,” says the Preacher,
“adding one thing to another to find the sum,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which my soul still seeks
    but I do not find:
One man among a thousand I have found,
    but a woman among all these I have not found.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, this only have I found:
    that God made man upright,
    but they have sought out many schemes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is like a wise man?
    And who knows the interpretation of a matter?
A man’s wisdom makes his face shine,
    and the harshness of his face is softened.
speaker: Narrator

text: I say, “Keep the king’s command, because of your oath to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be hasty to leave his presence. Do not take a stand in an unpleasant matter, for he does whatever pleases him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the word of the king is powerful, and who would say to him, “What are you doing?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who keeps his command will know no evil thing;
    and a wise heart will know the appropriate time and just way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For to every matter there is an appropriate time and just way,
    though a man’s distress weighs heavily on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he does not know what will happen;
    for who can declare to him what will occur?
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is not a man with mastery over the wind to restrain it,
    nor with power over the day of death.
And no one can discharge a battle,
    nor can wickedness rescue the one possessing it.
speaker: Narrator

text: All this I saw while applying my heart to every work that is done under the sun, when one man rules over another to the other’s hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw the wicked buried. They used to go in and out of the holy place, and they were praised in the city where they did works. This is also vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because the sentence against an evil deed is not executed swiftly, the heart of the sons of men is fully set to do evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since one who sins may do evil a hundred times and extend his life, I also have experienced that it will be good for those who fear God when they have reverence before Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it will not be well for the wicked, and he will not prolong his days, like a shadow, because he does not fear before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a vanity that takes place on the earth that there are righteous men who are treated according to the deeds of the wicked, and there are wicked men who are treated according to the deeds of the righteous. I said that this also is vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I commend joy, for man has nothing better under the sun than to eat and drink and be joyful; for this will go with him in his labor all the days of his life that God has given him under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I set my heart to know wisdom and to experience the affairs that are done on earth, though day and night there is no sleep for one’s eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I saw all the work of God, that a man cannot comprehend the work that is done under the sun. Inasmuch as a man labors to seek, he will not understand. Even if a wise man claims to know, he cannot grasp it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I considered all this in my heart, so that I could declare it all: that the deeds of the righteous and the wise are in the hand of God. No man knows whether love or hate awaits them; both are before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The same fate comes to all: There is one fate for the righteous and the wicked, for the good and the evil, for the clean and the unclean, for him who sacrifices and him who does not sacrifice.
As is the good,
    so is the sinner;
he who takes an oath
    as he who fears an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is an evil in all that is done under the sun: that the same event happens to all. Truly the hearts of the sons of men are filled with evil, and folly is in their hearts while they have life, and after that they go to the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for him who is joined to all the living there is hope, for a living dog is better than a dead lion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The living know that they will die,
    but the dead know nothing;
they have no more reward,
    for the memory of them is forgotten.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What they loved, hated,
    and envied has already perished;
and there is no reward for them from long ago
    in everything that is done under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and eat your food with gladness, and drink your wine with a pleasant heart; for God is already pleased with your deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text: At all times may your clothing be white, and let not oil ever lack on your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enjoy life with the wife whom you love all the days of your vain life which He has given you under the sun; because that is your reward in life and in your toil because you have labored under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever your hands find to do, do with your strength; for there is no work or planning or knowledge or wisdom in Sheol, the place where you are going.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Again I saw under the sun that—
the race is not to the swift,
    nor the battle to the strong,
nor food to the wise,
    nor riches to the intelligent,
    nor favor to those with knowledge;
but time and chance happen to them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For man does not know his time:
Like fish caught in an unfortunate net,
    like birds caught in a snare,
so the sons of men are ensnared at a tragic, yet appointed time,
    when it suddenly falls on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have also seen this wisdom under the sun, and it seemed great to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a small city with a few men in it; and a great king came and surrounded it, and he built up great siege works against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a poor, wise man was found there, and he himself in his wisdom delivered the city, but no one remembered that poor man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, “Wisdom is better than strength; yet the poor man’s wisdom is despised, and his words are not heard.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the wise heard in quietness are better
    than the shouting of a ruler among fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is better than weapons of war,
    but only one sinner can destroy much that is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A dead fly causes a stench in mixed anointing oil,
    so a little folly is more weighty than wisdom and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heart of the wise inclines to the right,
    but the heart of a fool to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even when a fool walks on the road,
    he lacks sense,
    and he shows everyone that he is a fool.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
There is an evil that I have seen under the sun
    like an error that goes out from a ruler:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Folly is set in many high places,
    but the rich sit in a low place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen slaves riding on horses,
    and officials walking along the ground like slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who digs a pit will fall into it,
    and whoever breaks through a wall will be bitten by a serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who quarries stones is injured by them,
    and he who splits wood is in danger from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If an iron piece is blunt
    and there is no one to sharpen it,
then he must prevail with more strength;
    but wisdom is a benefit to succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a serpent bites before it is charmed,
    there is no advantage to the charmer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of a wise man’s mouth bring favor,
    but the speech of a fool consumes him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness,
    and the end of his talk is evil madness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The labor of the foolish makes him weary,
    such that he does not know the way to the city!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to you, O land, when your king is a lad,
    and your princes are feasting in the morning!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Happy are you, O land, when your king is from nobility,
    and your princes are feasting at the appropriate time—
    with self-control and not drunkenness!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The roof beams sink in with slothfulness,
    and with the idleness of one’s hands the house drips.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Cast your bread upon the waters,
    for you will find it after many days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give a portion to seven, or even eight,
    for you do not know what calamity may happen on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the clouds are full of rain,
    they empty out on the land;
and if a tree falls to the north or south,
    in the place that the tree falls, there it will be.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who observes the wind will not sow,
    and he who regards the clouds will not reap.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As you do not know the way of the wind,
    or how the bones grow in the womb of her who is with child;
likewise you do not know the work of God
    who has made everything.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the morning sow your seed,
    and in the evening do not let your hand rest;
because you do not know which activity will find success,
    this way or that way,
    or if the both will be good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Light is sweet,
    and good for the eyes to see the sun;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for if a man lives many years,
    may he rejoice in all of them.
But let him also remember
    that the days of darkness are many.
    Everything that comes is vanity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Take away anger from your heart,
    and remove distress from your body,
    for youth and the dawn are vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator
    in the days of your youth,
before the difficult days come
    and the years arrive when you say,
    “I have no pleasure in them”:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
when they are afraid of heights,
    even the terrors along the road;
the almond tree blossoms,
    the grasshopper drags itself along
    and desire fails,
because man goes to his eternal home,
    and the mourners go about the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator before the cord of silver is snapped,
    or the bowl of gold smashed,
or the jar by the spring broken
    or the wheel at the cistern crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The dust returns to the earth where it was,
    and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is all vanity, says the Preacher;
    all is vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in addition to being wise, the Preacher still taught the people knowledge, and he considered, sought out, and arranged many proverbs.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Preacher sought to discover words of delight, and to write in uprightness words of truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of the wise are like goads, and the collected sayings are like firmly embedded nails, given by one shepherd.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, beware of anything beyond these.
Of making many books there is no end, and much study is a weariness to the flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now all has been heard.
    Let us hear the conclusion of the matter:
Fear God and keep His commandments,
    for this is the whole duty of man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God will bring every deed into judgment,
    including every secret thing,
    whether good or evil.
speaker: Narrator
